items.title: International bank chiefs throw support behind Jerome Powell
items.description: Twelve central bankers, including Australia's Reserve Bank governor Michele Bullock, have signed a letter in support of Mr Powell, who is set to face a criminal investigation in the US.

items.title: Ukraine hit by almost 300 drones, Volodymyr Zelenskyy says
items.description: Four people have been killed in the latest strikes by Russia that have mainly targeted the power grid.

items.title: Japan, South Korea agree to joint DNA testing for 1942 mine disaster victims

featured_image.name: Japan-South Korea Summit Takes Place In Nara

items.description:
Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi and South Korean President Lee Jae Myung met in Nara, Japan, on Tuesday to strengthen bilateral ties and regional cooperation as Tokyo faces intensifying economic pressure from Beijing over its stance on Taiwan.

"Cooperation between our two countries is more important than ever," Lee said at the opening of the summit in Takaichi's hometown, calling on both nations to work toward "a better future" amid "a complex and dizzying international order."[1][2] Takaichi responded that both countries should "cooperate to ensure regional stability and fulfill their respective roles."[3]

items.title: Webb telescope overturns decades of thinking on black hole behavior

featured_image.name: James Webb telescope finds 'remarkable' evidence that a ...

items.description:
NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has overturned decades of scientific thinking about supermassive black holes, revealing that hot, dusty material near the Circinus Galaxy's central black hole is primarily feeding it rather than being expelled outward as previously believed.

The research, published Tuesday in Nature, includes what NASA describes as the sharpest image of a black hole's surroundings ever captured by Webb[1][2].

items.title: SpaceX to bring ISS astronauts home in first medical evacuation

featured_image.name: SpaceX Crew-11 returning to Earth this week after astronaut suffers ‘medical concern': NASA

items.description:
The past week has marked a whirlwind of activity for SpaceX and NASA, with the successful launch of the Pandora exoplanet telescope followed by preparations for what will be the first medical evacuation from the International Space Station in its 25-year history.

NASA's Pandora mission lifted off aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California on January 11, joining a rideshare flight that SpaceX dubbed "Twilight" for its destination in a dusk-dawn sun-synchronous orbit[1][2]. The 325-kilogram spacecraft, equipped with a 45-centimeter all-aluminum telescope, will study at least 20 known exoplanets over its one-year primary mission[1][2].

items.title: Heat waves overwhelm honey bees' ability to cool hives, study finds

featured_image.name: Extreme heat waves disrupt honey bee thermoregulation and ...

items.description:
A new study reveals that intensifying heat waves are overwhelming honey bees' natural ability to cool their hives, causing population declines that could threaten global pollination services. The research, published on January 12 in the journal Ecological and Evolutionary Physiology, is the first to assess how natural heat waves affect honey bee colonies' capacity to regulate temperature and maintain healthy populations.[1][2]

The findings arrive as commercial beekeepers across North America already face colony losses potentially reaching 60 to 70 percent in recent years, according to Washington State University entomologists, underscoring the urgency of understanding how climate change compounds existing threats to these critical pollinators.[3]

items.title: Unstable water cycle drove nearly 5,000 deaths in 2025, report finds

featured_image.name: Climate change wreaking havoc on world's water cycle: UN

items.description:
Water-related disasters caused nearly 5,000 deaths, displaced 8 million people, and resulted in economic losses exceeding US$360 billion during 2025, according to a new international report that attributes these catastrophes to an increasingly unstable global water cycle driven by rapid warming.

The 2025 Global Water Monitor Report, released Sunday by researchers led by Professor Albert van Dijk at The Australian National University's Fenner School of Environment and Society, documents how shifts in rainfall patterns, atmospheric moisture, and temperature combined to amplify floods, droughts, and heat extremes worldwide[1][2][3].

items.title: Mars shapes Earth's ice ages despite its small size, study finds

featured_image.name: Scientists reveal Mars' unexpected role in Earth's long-term ...

items.description:
Despite being half the size of Earth and only one-tenth its mass, Mars exerts a measurable influence on our planet's long-term climate patterns, including the timing of ice ages, according to new research published this week.

The study, led by Stephen Kane, a professor of planetary astrophysics at the University of California, Riverside, used computer simulations to model how Earth's orbit and axial tilt would behave with and without Mars present in the solar system. The findings, published in Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, reveal that two major climate cycles vanish entirely when the red planet is removed from the equation.[1][2]

items.title: Louise Adler unloads over reputationally 'trashed' Adelaide Writers' Week
items.description: The former Adelaide Writers' Week director takes aim at lobby groups and the SA premier during an intense appearance on 7.30 in which she says the event's reputation has been "trashed".

items.title: Liberals divided over Labor's plan to outlaw inciting racial hatred
items.description: After weeks criticising the Albanese government over the Bondi attack and issues around antisemitism, the Coalition is split over whether proposed solutions are at odds with its interests in preserving freedom of speech.

items.title: Iranians bypass blackout with Starlink as phone calls resume

featured_image.name: Iran Appears to Be Jamming Starlink Amid Protests, Internet Blackout

items.description:
On Tuesday, Iranians were able to make international phone calls for the first time since their government imposed a near-total communications blackout on January 8, even as some citizens continue accessing the internet through Elon Musk's Starlink satellite service. The partial restoration of communications came as activists reported that at least 646 people have been killed in a bloody government crackdown on nationwide protests.[1][2][3]

Several people in Tehran were able to call The Associated Press, though calls from outside Iran could not reach them. Witnesses reported that SMS text messaging remained blocked and internet users could only access government-approved domestic websites, while international connections stayed severed.[1][2]

items.title: Iran restores some international calls amid ongoing blackout
items.description:
Mobile phones in Iran were able to call abroad on Tuesday after a deadly crackdown on nationwide protests in which the government severed both internet access and international calling capabilities, according to the Associated Press. Several people in Tehran were able to reach an AP journalist, though the news agency's bureau in Dubai could not call those numbers back[1][2].

The partial restoration comes as the country enters its fifth day of a near-total communications blackout that has isolated millions of Iranians from the outside world. According to NetBlocks, the internet monitoring organization, connectivity throughout the country remains at just 1% of normal levels[3][4]. Text messaging appeared to remain down, and witnesses confirmed the internet was still inaccessible[1][2].

items.title: Online retailer accused of trying to profit from Bondi massacre
items.description: An online fashion retailer accused of "unconscionable conduct" has been investigated for profiting off the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: Japan and South Korea pledge deeper ties at Nara summit

featured_image.name: Seoul, Tokyo arranging Lee-Takaichi summit in mid-January in Japan's Nara: report

items.description:
Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi and South Korean President Lee Jae Myung met in the ancient city of Nara on Tuesday for a summit aimed at deepening economic and security cooperation as the two U.S. allies navigate an increasingly complex regional landscape shaped by China's growing assertiveness and North Korea's nuclear program.

The meeting, held in Takaichi's home prefecture, marks the third encounter between the two leaders since Takaichi took office in October 2025 and carries added significance as this year marks 60 years since Japan and South Korea normalized diplomatic relations[1][2].

items.title: Author Craig Silvey not cooperating with authorities after arrest, court told
items.description: One of Australia's most renowned authors, Craig Silvey, faces court after he allegedly distributed child exploitation material.

items.title: 'We don't want them': Neo-Nazi group says it will disband ahead of new laws
items.description: In a statement posted to Telegram, the group announced the closure of the National Socialist Network would also spell the end of "co-projects" White Australia, the European Australian Movement and the White Australia Party.

items.title: James Webb telescope reveals how black holes starved early galaxies

featured_image.name: These 'impossible' galaxies are breaking the Universe as we know it

items.description:
A series of discoveries announced this week are reshaping astronomers' understanding of the early universe, revealing unexpected heat, unusual galaxy types, and cosmic structures that defy existing models of how the first galaxies formed and evolved.

Research published January 12 in Nature Astronomy describes a massive galaxy that "lived fast and died young" after its supermassive black hole slowly starved it of the cold gas needed to form new stars. Meanwhile, separate findings presented at the 247th meeting of the American Astronomical Society in Phoenix show galaxy clusters far hotter than predicted and objects so strange that scientists are comparing them to the platypus.[1][2][3]

items.title: Iran using 'military-grade' jamming to take down Musk's Starlink
items.description: Human rights groups estimate more than 500 people have been killed and more than 10,600 arrested in the ongoing protests.

items.title: The sort of world in which Rudd has lived most of his career is now gone
items.description: One month after Kevin Rudd leaves his post as Australia's ambassador to Washington, Donald Trump will make his first presidential visit to China in almost 10 years.

items.title: Three people rescued from central Queensland flood as ex-Cyclone Koji moves west
items.description: A clean-up is under way at Clermont, which remains cut off by floodwaters, as already-saturated western communities are being warned of possible heavy rains.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
